titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Eastern Parkway Coalition records 2007.016
titlestmt.author: John Zarrillo

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-20 16:36:40 +0000.

change.item: Reprocessed by Alice Griffin to rehouse records and oversize items.

physdesc.extent: in eight record cartons, one oversize flat box, ten flat file folders, and two rolled storage boxes.

did.abstract: The collection is composed of the records of the Eastern Parkway Coalition, dating from 1952 to 2007 (bulk dates, 1970-2007). These records are primarily composed of Constance Lesold's subject files. The subject files document many issues which affected the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn. These issues include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, and urban renewal. In addition to subject files, the records include a series of plans and maps for the reconstruction of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the area from the 1970s and 1980s.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Eastern Parkway Coalition records, 2007.016, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Folder titles in brackets were supplied by the archivist. Preservation photocopies were made of all of the newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection is composed of Constance Lesold's records of the Eastern Parkway Coalition, dating from 1952 to 2007 (bulk dates, 1970-2007). These records are primarily composed of subject files, which document issues that affected the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn. These issues include include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, drug use, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, and urban renewal. In addition to subject files, the records include a series of plans and maps for the reconstruction of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the area.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are organized into two series:

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Eastern Parkway Coalition (EPC) is a community organization based in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn. Established in the 1970s, the organization ran summer youth programs, many of which focused on community improvement and gardening. The group established a community garden atop the Franklin Avenue Shuttle subway station at the Botanic Garden/Eastern Parkway/Union Street. In 1989, New York City Transit Police demolished the community garden with the intention of clearing the land for a parking lot. The garden was later reestablished due to community outrage and is now known as the Union Street Garden and Community Development.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Constance "Connie" Lesold was born in North Carolina in 1938. She first visited the Brooklyn neighborhood of Crown Heights in 1966 and had an apartment with her husband, Helmuth Lesold, by 1967. The couple had one son, Benjamin, who was born in 1970. She is a social worker, who was president of the Parkway Independent Democrats and an official of Community Board Eight. Along with her husband, several Brooklyn community boards, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and a public coalition, she opposed the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's move to end service on the Franklin Avenue Shuttle in the mid-1990s. She volunteered with the Brooklyn Mental Hygiene Court Monitors Project and became a member of Disabled in Action. In 2004, she joined a group occupying a firehouse that shut down service in Williamsburg. Lesold joined lawmakers and citizens at the Capitol in Albany to protest rent control regulations in 2015 and she remains an active participant in MTA Board hearings.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Center for Brooklyn History holds the following related materials:
- Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation Oral History collection, 2007-2008 (2008.030)
- West Indian Carnival Documentation Project records, 1993-1996 (2010.019)
- Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation publication and photograph collection, 1968–2007 (ARC.124)
- Brooklyn neighborhood associations and civic organizations publications, 1881-2010 (ARC.167)
- Voices of Crown Heights oral histories, 2016-2017 (2016.027)
- Listen to This: Crown Heights Oral History collection, 2010 (2010.020)
The New York Public Library holds the following related materials:

phystech.p: Most of the materials in Series 2: Plans and maps are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact cbhreference@bklynlibrary.org for more information about access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains subject files of Constance Lesold's work with the Eastern Parkway Coalition and includes documents dating from 1952 to 2007.

The files were maintained by Constance Lesold, who was also an active member of other community groups, such as Community Boards 8 and 9, the Brooklyn Tenants Union, and local block associations. Files related to those other organizations appear frequently in the series.

The series documents several topics relating to the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn from the 1970s to the early 2000s. These subjects include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, drug use, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, the Haitian community, and urban renewal.

Community gardens are especially well represented in the files, especially the Franklin Avenue Shuttle Garden, which was demolished by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in 1989. Controversy over the Brooklyn Botanic Garden charging entrance fees is also addressed in the series.
Cultural affairs are also featured in the series, especially the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Public Library, and the New Muse.
The files are primarily composed of flyers, publications, correspondence, memoranda, and clippings. A small amount of files include photographs, slides, negatives, and audio cassettes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

did.unittitle: [Eastern Parkway Coalition exhibition at New Muse and photographs]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs included in these folders may have been exhibited as a part of the exhibition. The photographs depict dying elms, unidentified garden clean-up and advocacy events, a Lincoln Terrace Park clean-up event, installation of historic markers along Eastern Parkway, and a protest against the closing of the Franklin Avenue Shuttle. Hattie Carthan and Ruth Goring are in some of these photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains plans and maps for the reconstruction and redevelopment of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the Prospect Heights and Crown Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn, dating from 1973 to 1986. The series also includes district maps and plans for playground reconstruction. The plans and maps were produced by the City of New York.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Most of the materials in this series are stored offsite offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact cbhreference@bklynlibrary.org at least two weeks prior to research visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is intellectually arranged by date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These folders contain New York City Department of Transportation Bureau of Highway Operations blueprints dated October 27, 1986 for the rehabilitation of Eastern Parkway from Washington Avenue to Pitkin Avenue. The Federal Project number is IXA - 504B and the contract number is THCK 170B. The plans cover traffic signals, park removals, lampposts and luminaires, electrical layout, and subway ventilators.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Photographs of this project may be held by the New York City Municipal Archives: Accession ACC-1998-016. Unprocessed - RG 046. Department of Transportation Bureau of Highway Operations contractual repair photographs, negatives, and color slides for 1929 to 1982.
